On Fri, 13 Jun 2003 16:54:16 -0700, "Eric Armstrong"
<eric.armstrong@...> said:
[snip]
> There is no "get" in this system, but the test can still verify
> that the internal state is as expected, using state-verification
> methods intended for that purpose.

Interesting points.  My general take on the matter is that there is no
one answer.  I think the system itself will dictate the best approach. 
One thing that I do feel very strongly about is that a plethora or
getters/setters tends to indicate that the object design is faulty.  I
think that goes more for the setters than the getters.  It's my
contention, and I code this way every day of the week, that an object
should be instantiated in a sane state.  You should not need to 'new' an
object and then turn right back around a call 1..N setter methods on it.

> (Open question: Should such a method return a boolean or throw
> an exception??)

Depends...  What is the rest of the error handling like in the system? 
Can you recover from the error (think of File.delete(...) -- it does
sometimes fail and there really isn't anything you can do about it at
that particular nanosecond in time)?  If so, why not just return the
boolean, it's more cost effective if nothing else.  Does it matter in the
long run whether or not you succeed?  I would argue yes, at least for the
designs I create and work with, but some might disagree sometimes.

Well, that's all...

--
=jason
